text: Bottle 2016 vintage. Pours a pitch black beer with a medium sized beige head on top. Aroma has lots of espresso,darker roasted coffee, dark chocolate. The coffee is very strong in this one, with a lot of roast in there. Flavor has lots coffee in there, basically only coffee in there, Lots of sweet syrup in there, dark chocolate and some vanilla in there. Awesome balance, very strong and overall great beer. Doesnt live up to the hype though. but still amazing.

W końcu. Cudowny aromat! Potężny syrop klonowy, kawa, paloność. Genialny balans - słodkie, kawowo-goryczkowe, piękny syrop klonowy, czekolada. Mega długi, intensywny, pozostający w całej jamie ustnej na długie minuty finisz. Wyśmienite piwo, zdecydowanie dorasta do swojej renomy.

Sampel butelki w Chmielarni. Batch 3. Piękny aromat kawy i syropu, ale rozwala dopiero w smaku. Epicki balans, palone, ale jednocześnie słodkie i gładkie, bez kawowej goryczki czy kwasu. Jest jak aksamit, jak mały jezusek tańczący na języku, delikatne ale też zajebiscie złożone. Wszystko jest razem świetnie dopasowane, nic nie wybija się ponad miarę, współgra z sobą i dąży do harmonii. Do tego mega pijalne, gdzie samemu można wypić całą butelkę i to w 15 minut. To jest właśnie geneza nazwy Mornin Delight, piłbym codziennie rano i każdy dzień byłby wtedy piękny.

Rami Rami is drinking a Mornin Delight by Toppling Goliath Brewing Co. at Chmielarnia Marszałkowska

2 albo 3 warka. Megakawa. Cynamon (wiekszosc osob sie nie zgadza). Ciastka. Palonosc. Slodkie dosc. Specyficzne. Delikatne i pijalne.
Rami Rami: Nie jest moze podoum swiatowe, ale tak, jest zajebiste
Rami Rami: Wyjatkowo zrownowazone, co jest przemile

Rami Rami: Bardzo fajnie gladkie cialoRami Rami: syrop klonowy nie taki oczywisty ale obecny. choc im bardziej o tym mysle, tym bardziej mam wrazenie, ze moj mozg dokonuje z racji intensywnosci transkrypcji: syrop -> cynamon :>Rami Rami: szklo nie moglo sie pozbyc tego aromatu megatrwalego ;)

650ml bottle. Black with short head. Incredible maple and coffee aroma. The tastes moves through sweeter chocolate and maple flavours before a bitter coffee onslaught. Very good but a bit below what Id hoped for.

Bottle 22fl.oz. shared at [ A Day To Sink All Sea Shepards tasting. ], Brussels, Belgium. [ As Toppling Goliath Mornin Delight ].[ Gold wax ]. Clear dark dark black color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, beige head. Aroma is heavy malty, rosted, coffee, dusty coffee - chocolate, strong coffee, espross0, light maple syrup. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and bitter with a long duration, sweet malt, molasses, maple syrup, dark malt, dark malt, chocolate - vanilla, coffee. Body is full, texture is oily - creamy, carbonation is soft, finish feel is light alcoholic. [20160917]
 9-4-9-5-18

Keg at Ratebeer Best Beer Festival. 31/01/2016. A viscous black brown coloured pour with a small dark tan head. oily. Aroma is big cinnamon, cakey, vanilla toffee, . Flavour is composed of lovely full smooth cakey malts, toffee, vanilla, little bourbon and wood. . Palate is full bodied, smooth and velvety.

The maple hit your nose as soon as the bottle was opened. Dark brown, almost black with a medium brown head when poured. The balance between the coffee and the maple was excellent. Medium bodied on the palate. Hard to believe it is not barrel aged. Very good beer.

Bottle at tads ( thank you thank you thank you) ...Dark black.. No real head.. Massive rich coffee.. Heavy rich roast... Heavy chocolate roast malts.. Dark sweet chocolate roast.. Big coffee... Rich thick body... Massive maple.. Heavy sweet maple coffee.
Bottle at tads. Pours black, nose is chocolate, coffee, caramel, roasted, coconut, taste is sweet, bitter coffee, roasted, chocolate, smoky, maple syrup.

Bottle. Pours black with a medium brown head. Aroma is coffee, maple, vanilla. Taste is coffee bitter, vanilla sweet, vanilla bitter, maple syrup sweet, cocoa bitter, chocolate sweet. Syrupy mouthfeel. Fucking intense!
Bottle thanks to Craig. Pours black with a chocolate brown head. huge maple syrup nose, viscous mouthfeel. Mild bitterness from the coffee.
Shared bottle. Pours black with a small brown head. Aroma of coffee, vanilla, maple, and malt. Taste is coffee, maple, roasted malt, vanilla, and some chocolate. Excellent.
No comment I can write here will do it justice. One of my favorite beers ever, tons of coffee, maple, and vanilla... delicious

Un immense merci à Yan pour le partage de cette grande bouteille en ce souper de Réveillon! Vintage 2016. Entre lépaule dagneau braisée et les fromages. À peine la capsule levée de la bouteille, une véritable explosion darômes dérable envahit la pièce. Du sirop dérable, de la tire dérable sur la neige, de la pâte à biscuits aux pépites de chocolat non cuite... De la véritable folie! Une fois dans mon verre cependant, les arômes sestompent curieusement rapidement. De mon verre séchappent beaucoup plus de vapeurs dérable que du verre de Marc-André. Je ressens encore beaucoup de chocolat mais surtout du café. Une base cependant verte me fait sourciller car cette dernière était la dernière chose à laquelle je mattendais. Le café demeure tout de même au centre de toute laction - au nez comme ne bouche. Des arômes de grains de café éthiopiens chauffés accentués par des brisures de chocolat au lait de qualité exceptionnelle. Et cette texture!!! Le liquide est léger comme une plume, voire aérien. Une légèreté satinée, moelleuse comme je nen ai jamais ressentie de semblable. Lérable me salue en passant en guise de rappel en laissant le chocolat et le café se disputer le premier rôle. Laisse moi pas tout seul avec un bomber car je laurai bu sans même men rendre compte. Un élixir Supérieur.

UPDATED: DEC 26, 2016 Bottle shared thanks to Charule. WTF? Top 5 beer? No. Top 50? No. Its good but basically can get this on the shelf and make yourself with some maple syrup. Just take Wake n Bake and add maple = MD. Huge letdown. Green pepper coffee too.

Bottle @ DB #25. Batch 3. Pitch black pour with a dense dark tan head. Notes of heavy roast, euro malts, light peat, roasted coffee, sweet bitter chocolate, caramel, vanilla and maple on the finish. Quite good!

Bottle. Batch 3. Pours Pitch black with a brown head. Aroma of fresh ground coffee, maple, vanilla, roasted malts, slight weak smoke, slight "green" coffee as well. fruity espresso, caramel and brown sugar. Taste is much more roasted than the aroma. Some maple syrup, ground coffee, vanilla, green bitter coffee, dry cocoa beans and weak caramel. Its overall a very good beer I think it is safe to say that I was let down by this beer. It smells amazing but I dont follow the extreme hype on this one. Maybe I got the wrong batch?

UPDATED: JAN 12, 2017 From bottle. Batch #3. Finally got to try this! Pours a pitch black with a nice, tan head. Aroma has a complete shit ton of coffee! Nice, toasty maple syrup, super roasty, light hop presence, green coffee. Taste is surprisingly unsweet. Lots of bitter roast, bitter coffee, intense lakritol-like licorice. Pretty spicy, lots of maple flavor but very little of the sweetness. Bitter, roasty after taste. Makes me realize that i didnt really knew what to expect from this beer, haha! Somewhat full body and a medium low carbonation. Really good stout, but dont get the hype on this one.
Batch 3 on tap at release in Decorah. Poured black with tan head. Aroma mega smooth coffee. Light carb med bod. Taste again with the smooth fresh brewed espresso light choc. Lil dry.

Bottle shared, batch two. Pitch black with short lasting dark brown head that leaves an oily film. Massive molasses, apple juice spread (applesirop), coffee, maple, pecan, brown sugar, light tart roasted barley. Theres actually a lot of coffee but it takes some time to come to the forefront. Taste is thick sweet with coffee bitterness and a light fruity/ashy sourness in the background. Full bodied with crazy thick syrupy feel, this needs a spoon! Very good, not the best beer in the world but its unique, interesting and very good.

Sampled from bottle shared by Maakun at his place. Big thanks! Black pour. Big sweet vanilla, deep roasted chocolate malts, cocoa, maple syrup, apples, coffee, molasses, roasted red paprika. Big sweet, mild bitter. Supple full bodied, very soft carbonation. Big sweet roasty finish. Crazy feel, crazy sweet. Nice roast. Like!
Draft at RB Best Fest 16: Poured a dark thick black with brown head. Aroma was strong with molasses and vanilla. Taste was coffee, sticky booze, molasses, and vanilla.

On tap and from a bottle. Pours out black topped with a small tan head. Nose is massive sweetness maple syrup roast malts vanilla coffee and plenty other adjuncts. Taste is more of the heavy sweetness a dark barrel notes. Good yes over hyped yes.

To be honest I hoped this wouldnt deliver, but it just blew me away in every way. 

Complex as hell with layer upon layer of awesomeness. Chocolate, licorice, coconut, maple syrup, vanilla and some gentle roasty notes that makes for a perfect finish.

May 28, 2016. Bottle. Shared by _angst_, thanks!
Black with a small brown head, some nice legs on the glass. Aroma is lots of sweet maple syrup backed up by fresh roasted ground coffee, some toffee, vanilla, light earthy notes. 
Taste is sweet, malty, roasted bitterness. Finish is quite bitter with roasted coffee and dark chocolate, some salty notes with hints of soy, licorice. Full bodied, soft carbonation, oily texture with a very light dry finish. 

Great, slightly too salty finish, but on the other hand that increases the drinkability.

Bomber received in trade. Thank you trogenmi. Pours oily pitch black with a creamy dark mocha head that leaves some lacing and trace on the glass while dissipating. Smell is malty, roasty and slightly woody with roasted malts, burnt caramel, toffee, high quality dark roast coffee, high quality dark chocolate, maple syrup, moist soil, leather and hints of alcohol. Taste is sweet, bitter, salty, malty and roasty. Mouthfeel is thick, viscous, creamy, round, slightly roasted astringent, tiny boozy and full bodied. Finish is sweet, bitter and salty with a heft delicious roasty malts, sea salt sprinkled dark chocolate, dark roast coffee and maple syrup. While its possibly a tiny bit salty this is just plain delicious. Complex and crazy rich. Love it!

Bottle at Wailin Whales in Linus apartment 160528. Opaque black beer with a beautiful brownish head. Lovely chocolate and coffee aroma, maple syrup, vanilla, milk chocolate, licorice notes, cocoa powder, ice coffee, tar notes, some raisins and figs. Chocolate flavor, maple syrup, cocoa powder, raisins, caramel, raisins, figs, kinda well hidden alcohol, salty, some dark chocolate. Great chocolate and coffee finish with licorice, salt and some raisins. Am-fuckin-azing!!!
A: Pitch black with a brown head N: Maple, coffee, chocolate, soy sauce, milk chocolate T: Maple syrup, coffee, salmiak, sea salt O: Extremly well balanced! Super nice coffee and maple! I love it!

This beer definitely lives up to hype. All you need is some patience. Shared a whole bottle with my lady. 
The first few sips were disappointing. Very much coffee forward, could taste some yummy caramel malt, just a hint of maple and chocolate at the end, extremely sticky and thick mouthfeel. But did it deserve the title of "one of the best imperial stouts" in the world? Hell nah. 
But it gets better. Much better. As the beer warms up, maple and chocolate flavor becomes much more dominant. On the other hand, coffee flavor mellows out. The best part is that the flavor lasts on your tongue forever. Orgasm in my mouth. Perhaps the best beer Ive ever tasted.
For those who were disappointed, Im telling you, wait until this beer warms up! I chilled on this bottle for 3 hours, and the flavor just kept on getting better and better... cant wait to try Kentucky Brunch.

Taproom tap poured motor oil dark brown with a thin tan head and oily lacing. Aromas of cocoa, vanilla, liquorice, vanilla, and coffee, with hints of boozy oak. Flavor has mild cocoa bitterness with a sweet chocolate finish. Amazing.

Huge flavors of black coffee, maple syrup, dark chocolate, vanilla bean and hints of the blackest plums imaginable. Intense hops carry the long finish, which really may be this brews greatest attribute. The maple adds a complex element that makes this a perfect beer to start your day. Tasted in line at Dark Lord Day 2016 at 7:30 am.

On tap at RateBeer Best 2016. Pour is black with a minimal coffee-colored head. Aroma and flavor of toasted almonds, chocolate syrup, strong maple, vanilla extract, pancakes, and fudge. Finish is chocolate pancakes + booze.

Pitch black. STRONG mocha, espresso aroma, some slight hint of syrup, high amount of roast. Feels thick on the tongue, strong coffee presence, maybe the most coffee forward beer I have ever had. Super complex though and tasty, acidy and carb levels perfection. Awesome sutff.

Tasted from draft at Hunahpu Day 16. Pours black with dark brown head. Aroma is maple syrup, bourbon, chocolate and coffee. Taste is super thick and chewy on the mouth. Lot of maple syrup. Flavors also of bourbon, vanilla, coffee, chocolate, dark fruits. Awesome beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
On tap at rbwg. Wow this was great. Looked like motor oil. Tasted like thick coffee and chocolaty amazingness.

Combining notes from bottle and draft pours. The beer is black with a small to medium light brown head. Pretty good retention for a big stout. The aroma is big and sweet and wonderful. Lots of coffee, chocolate and caramel with a big maple syrup and vanilla note. Coffee is mildly fruity with a nice gentle roast and stays in more of a supporting role than expected. All of that maple and vanilla makes it smell like some sort of delicious breakfast food dessert. Big fudgey chocolate Taste is sweet and provides more chocolate and coffee to balance out the maple, not that the aroma is unbalanced in a bad way. Nice, thick mouthfeel. Chewy stout goodness. I really, really like this beer.

Draft at RateBeer Best 2016. Pours oily black with a creamy brown head. Lots of ashy roast in the aroma, some dark chocolate, cocoa. Big sweet flavour, which clashes somewhat with a hard ashy aspect. There is also a lot of espresso and scorched earth. Full bodied, oily and chewy, with fine carbonation. Bitter finish with more baking cocoa, scorched earth, strong roast. A very good beer overall.

[1/31/16] Draught sample at RateBeer Best festival in Santa Rosa. Black, motor oil-like, thick and viscous. Huge chocolate, vanilla, bourbon, cookies, maple, nuts. Sweet. Really thick, slight booziness. Wonderful.

Keg at RB Best 16, 31/01/16.
Black toppped with a moderately appointed tan covering.
Nose is rich malt, chocolate, coffee grinds, light spice, tar.
Taste comprises chocolate, vanilla, dark fruit rinds, raisens, light spice, toffee fudge.
Full bodied, oliy feel, warming alcohol in the close.
Solid impy, well balanced, drinks below the ABV, good coffee hit.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: On tap at RateBeer Best 2016. It pours a dark brown color with a brown head. The aroma is extremely intense with coffee extract and mild hints of maple syrup. Very chocolaty as well. The flavor is equally intense with chocolate brownies, coffee and more mild hints of maple syrup thats perceived more in the mouth feel than the flavor. Coffee roast and chocolate in the finish. The body is very thick and decadent. Pretty awesome stuff. Glad to have tried it.
Shared bottle. Deep molasses, coffee, and chcolate notes. Palate is very, very sweet. Has a nice dark mahogony hue with a thin vanilla/tan head. Its a very good beer, dense with flavors.

UPDATED: FEB 8, 2016 Tap at the Rate Beer Awards Festival. Huge aroma of coffee and cocoa. Sweet, rich flavor of maple syrup, coffee, chocolate syrup. A bit of prickly pepper in the finish. Also some hints of raspberry and cherry. Really lovely stout. Pretty much lived up to the hype.

On tap at the RB festival 
Black with a medium sized tan head, lots of lacing. Aroma of dark malts and maple syrup. Tastes like eating pancakes with maple syrup  
This would be great with breakfast

Draught at RateBeer Best festival. Opaque black liquid with small tan head. Aroma of coffee, bourbon, chocolate, raw sugar, light ash, raisins and dried fruit. Taste is medium to high sweet and light bitter with notes of coffee, vanilla, bourbon and chocolate. Full bodied with low to medium carbonation. Great, very nice.
On tap st Rate Beer Best. Pours dark brown with a modest tan head and a chocolate and treacle aroma. There is a magnificent dark molasses flavor with dark coffee and a dry finish. Excellent!

On tap at ratebeer best. Opaque black pour with brown head. Aroma is so rich beautiful coffee aroma, super sweet, rich chocolate. Taste is super coffee forward, rich caramel, sweet roasty flavor. Palate is rich, super heavy, good carbonation.

(22oz bomber) thick and viscous, dark espresso brown, tan bubbles. The nose has an odd combo of maple and coffee that smells vegetal to me. Some acrid nature to it also. Rich and chocolaty, oaky and tannins. Taste of bitter coffee, dark chocolate, fairly rich, huge viscosity, the amount of maple, chocolate and coffee is just huge. Perhaps slightly out of balance but its huge and has few equals in that respect. A unique beer thats awesome.

Poured from a bottle. 
Aroma is nice with a lot of maple syrup notes and some medium light coffee notes. Some nice dark chocolate notes. Some nice caramel notes too. 
Pours black with a small, thick, dark mocha head with decent retention as it recedes to the edges where it lingers for just a bit. Light lacing and medium long legs. 
Flavor has a lot of maple syrup notes. Some lighter coffee notes. Moderate dark chocolate notes with some light roast. Rather sweet from the syrup but moderate bitterness and a bit of astringency in the finish. Some toffee and caramel notes. 
Mouthfeel is full bodied with medium low carbonation. Medium low astringency and low alcohol warmth. 
Overall, a nice, very maple forward beer. A bit too astringent for me and the coffee wasnt as prevalent as I would like.

Sampled from bottle (shared with Joes, Dutchdrebus and Koen) @ "Het is allemaal de schuld van Koen" tasting. Opaque pitch black color, medium to full sized dark brown head that diminishes fairly quickly. Aroma is malts, dark chocolate, creme brulee, some (Dutch) "hopjesvla" which -unfortunately- I really dislike. Taste malts, dark chocolate, liquorice bitterness, coffee roast, again (Dutch) "hopjesvla", sweet maple syrup, bitter finish. Medium body and carbonation. Unfortunately not my kind of beer as I dont like the sweet maple syrup and hopjesvla flavor.

Bottle @ joes goes whale hunting tasting. Pitch black colour, medium sized brown head. Smells maple syrup, sweet roasty, chocolate. Lovely. Tastes chocolate, cocoa, maple syrup, sweet, vanilla, creme brulee, Haagse hopjes, amazing. Love it. Full body, low carbo.
Pours thick and motor oil black with a thin mocha head. Aroma is weird, slightly vegetal. Taste is amazing, maple, coffee and bakers chocolate. Wow this is special

Black thick pour from bottle at home. Tan head. Syrupy, cocoa and maple aroma. Coffee, chocolate, maple, maybe some burnt leaves. Huge flavor - a ton going on. Good stuff, wouldn't say it's worth the price people are paying.

Cracking open maple syrup hits you in the nose. Taste is sweet, maple syrup, some hazelnut and some coffee. No taste of alcohol whatsoever. Pours reddish brown with a tan head. Really great stout out of toppling Goliath. Very light on the pallete. Not worth 400.00 though.

Consumed on Christmas with my friend. Figured Id break it out finally, most recent vintage. Poured a thick, oily deep brown and black with a bubbly khaki head. Aroma immediately hits you with strong notes of espresso and maple with lighter notes of vanilla and chocolate. Flavor was heavy and strong espresso forward with maple and vanilla. Bit of chocolate there too. Full body with a thick oily texture, perfect carbonation, and a bit of a bitter coffee finish. Absolutely wonderful and very glad I was able to get and try this beer!

2015 bottle. 4 months old. Huuuuuuuge thanks to Couch for sharing! Aroma is huge espresso, light smoke, maple syrup, and chocolate. Moderate to strong sweetness. Huge maple and espresso. Lots of vanilla, some smoke, bread dough and chocolate chip cookies. Mouthfeel is slightly thinner than I would prefer. Overall its delicious but not top 10.
One of the best stouts I have ever tasted. It is a maple, roasty bomb of flavor and has an incredible mouth feel. Sticks to the glass and pours really thick. Cant wait to drink this again!

Mornin delight batch 2

Pours an oily, black color, with a medium, dark brown head to it, revealing huge bubbles within a spongy head. Coates the side of the glass after swirling with alcohol legs, small bubbles and an oily film, showcasing the thickness of the beer.

Smells of warming syrup, wrapped up by cold pressed coffee beans, together with scorched, earthy malts. Atop of that foundation settles a nutty and raisiny quality, both adding to the potent coffee appearance. Milk chocolate enriches the luscious, sweet maple syrup, with coffee cutting through in a flowery, slightly wooden fashion. The most beautiful thing about the aromas is their perfect balance in combination to its outstanding intensity. 

Drinks outstandingly smooth, soft on the tongue with a lower carbonation to it, presenting the beers huge body perfectly. Even its profound coffee bitterness during the finish is not able to distract from its creamy softness, maintaining its fantastic thickness.

Tastes of oaken, multi layered espresso bean, pungent, while offering a pleasant, mellowing sweetness, which gets beautifully enhanced by the syrup. An early, dry coffee bitterness goes hand in hand with earthen, toasted malts and a brewed coffee sourness, almost completely wrapped up by the malts. Into this coffee sourness blends the rich maple syrup, creating an intriguing flavor depth, soothed by whipped cream. During the beers finish, its profound coffee earthiness returns to the palate, while bitter chocolate compliments it, together with perfumy, alcohol soaked praline.

While featuring chewy, sweeter qualities, the beer reveals an awesome balance, due to its mvp, the coffee. It is incredibly rich and exhibits both, sweeter and bitter qualities by itself, accentuated by syrup and malts. Its mouthfeel makes this truly great, maintaining a remarkable silkness on the tongue, while the beers rich, thick body is challenging the tastebuds throughout, in the most pleasant way, coating my tongue for minutes after each sip.

Had this beer a couple of times over the last few years. What an unbelievable beer from Toppling Goliath. It smells like the perfect stout with dark black chocolate appearance. Taste of chocolate, coffee with a hint of the vanilla and maple that create the perfect balance. Just hits your palate perfectly. Overall one of the best stouts Ive had and look forward to trying it again.

UPDATED: DEC 10, 2016 Rating #1000! Oh yeahhh. Bottle thanks to Mikkel. Thank you so much for this treat! Pours pitch black with a thick medium mocha head. The aroma of this beer is so full of maple. Its surprising. Didnt expect it to have THIS much. Wow. Lots of vanilla, dry dark chocolate, cocoa powder, oak, dry roasted coffee, walnut, hazelnut. The taste is just as fantastic. Dry rich dark chocolate, maple, caramel, vanilla fudge, roasted coffee, milk chocolate. So rich and full. Damn. 9/5/9/5/18 - on 12/6/2015 


Bottle shared. Pours pitch black with a small thick mocha head. Aromas of huge sweet maple, roast, bitter coffee, chocolate, vanilla, nuts, fudge. Taste is roasty, bitter, chocolate, sweet maple, green coffee, sweet fudge. 9/5/8/5/17 - on 10/12/2016

Bottle shared in the line for Mikkeller bar Aarhus grand opening, courtesy of Mikkel, thanks! Pours pitch black with a creamy brown head. Aroma of roasted malt, caramel, coffee, coffee grounds, vanilla, hazelnuts, dark chocolate, marple syrup. Falvor is rather sweet, rich malty, coffee, expresso, chocolate, vanilla, nutty, marple syrup, alcohol. Medium to full body, oily mouthfeel, soft carbonation, light sweet finish with warming alcohol. 271115
Draft at Parlor City. OMG! Pours black with no head. Nose and taste is a little coffee, big maple, caramel and bourbon. Great!

Just as the Americans like it, sweet as hell and full of things that just dont belong in a beer, such as coffee flavor. It is very aromatic though, and if you like that a beer tastes like hot chocolate coffee with beer flavor, then this is the stuff for you. Soon to find in your next Sturbucks!

Taste: sweet maple, malty, Espresso coffee bean, rich chocolate notes.
Black as midnight in color, Opaque as oil.
Bold, coffee and maple aroma.
Heavy body.
cocoa colored head with sticky lace.
Boozy, thick finish, and massive enough to pour over ice cream.
Had on tap at Toppling Goliath on the bottle release day. Perfect balance between coffee maple malt and alcohol. Top notch

UPDATED: JAN 10, 2016 bottle shared at the Moeder Lambic cellar session 2015. new bomber bottle from the latest release. poured one of the most dark oily black colours ive ever seen on a imperial stout, with a dark mocha coloured head that stays on forever. with some nice lacing on the side of the glass. while pouring the nose is hit with an incredible dark roasted espresso smell, followed by sweet dark roasted malts, sticky syrup. toasted almonds, sweet bakers chocolate, mocha. really just smells like a morning breakfast pancake covered with dark coffee maple. the smell is just a clear 10 out of 10. however the taste can not follow the nose. there is still that dark chocolate coffe roast, with vanilla, and maple syrup, and maybe a bit overpowered by the coffee. but there is missing something. the mouthfeel is thick and viscious. and the look keeps amazing untill the last sip. glad i finally got to try this one

Bottle shared by Damian and Lona. Pours an opaque deep dark black with a ring of toffee colored head. Aroma is roasty malts and coffee, booze, and sweetness. Taste is amazing, roasted malts and nice coffee, sweetness from the syrup, vanilla, and booze. So good.

Yesterday at the 2015 release.

L: Very dark, no light gets through this one. As the beer moves around the glass, it coats and sticks to the side, pretty sure my chalice is permanently brown. Thin caramely head with good retention.

S: Huge maple and coffee nose. The entire taproom smelled like brunch during the release. Most aromatic beer I have had.

T: Maple not as big as nose would suggest, but still huge and controlling. The roasty coffee comes through amazingly as well, chocolately roasty, not bitter roasty. The beer is extremely smooth, would not guess it is a 12% stout.

MF: Amazing. Absolutely perfect viscosity/thick feel for a non BA stout.

Overall: Hands down the best adjunct stout Ive ever had. The bottle count on this is significantly higher that the last run, so get your hands on one if you can. Another heavy hitter from TG.
Fantastic beer. Tastes like breakfast in a glass! Aroma was boozy when cold but was nothing but maple, coffee, and pancakes after it warmed. Taste was same with a crazy amount of body. Delicious!

On tap at Dexters during Great Taste Eve. Big thick black body. Huge aroma of coffee. Slick sticky mouthfeel. Hell, this beer is very sticky. Taste was huge coffee. Cant understate how much coffee flavor is in there. Probably more than the average extra dark roast coffee from the local coffee cafe. Has lots of sweet maple flavor to cut through the coffee. One thing I didnt like was that is was kind of tart. This might have been the coffee though. Still, I didnt care for the tart taste.

GTMW...obviously good, but not crazy. Super coffee and spice aroma...flat black color, taste is supper coffee and spice. Palate is really chalky...not my thing. Would seek out again...but not stand in a fest line...much less trade big.

UPDATED: SEP 11, 2015 From notes. Enjoyed at the Great Taste of the Midwest on August 08. The pour is a viscous and tar-like black with a thin dark brown head that settles to a small ring and offers some great staining on the glass. The aroma is all coffee up front and absolutely beautiful. There is a great complexity of maple, a little bit of green oak and vanilla. A fudgy chocolate backs everything up. It smells like a fudge. The taste is unbelievable. Heavy coffee, that unbelievable maple, a great chocolate, moderate vanilla, and a light bourbon presence. This baby tastes like a maple-soaked coffee fudge. My god. The mouth feel is unbelievable. Its like chewing fudge. Thick, viscous, with a soft carbonation. This baby just coats the mouth and refuses to leave. The aftertaste is all maple. Sweet, delicious, unbelievable. Best liquid Ive ever had in my mouth, hands down.

UPDATED: SEP 4, 2015 Tap at GTMW Aug 2015. Pours an inky black with mocha lined heading. Nose is mostly maple accompanied by a bit of chocolate, vanilla, and coffee. Taste is subdued dark chocolate, strong organic maple character (as opposed to extract or flavoring), and finishes with coffee and slight acidity. Body seems thin and over carbonated, but even with all that said it was quite a treat!
9/4/15 rerate: Tried from tap at release with appropriate carbonation and a much better experience overall.

UPDATED: AUG 10, 2015 Sample at Great Taste of the Midwest. Aroma is coffee, maple, fresh oak. Awesome. Appearance is thick, black with brown head. Taste is coffee, maple, chocolate, vanilla, smooth. Mouthfeel is incredibly thick, oily, perfect. Overall....this beer is all of the hype and more.
Draft sample at Dexters. Black color, brown head. Aroma of rich espresso. Taste has vanilla, fruity rich coffee, dark bittersweet cocoa. Delicious.

Smells like glorious coffee with maple syrup. Just wonderful. Thick, creamy, sticky mouthfeel. Maple, coffee, chocolate, and a bit of booze. Absolutely superb, having this again just confirms that its my all-time favorite beer.

Beautiful legs upon pouring this sexy beast. Aroma of roast malt, coffee and cocoa. TASTE IS AMAZING! chocolate malt, SWEET maple coffee and graham cracker with maple aftertaste. The best beer I have ever had.

Originally reviewed 7/1/2013. 12 oz. bottle poured into a snifter. Inky black with a small mocha head. Wisps on the surface. Stains the glass nicely.

Incredible aroma. Coffee and maple. The maple is incredible. Dark chocolate. Like a giant Maple Bacon Coffee Porter.
Coffee is more prominent. in the taste. Strong coffee and even a bit abrasive. Delicious maple. Dark chocolate. Boozier here too. Coffee lingers in the aftertaste. Even a little smokey in the aftertaste. 

Chewy. Nice and thick. Medium carbonation. 

This is delicious. Smells better than it tastes but its pretty damn good.

bottle at The Ultimate Imperial Stout Tasting 2015 - all props to Kevin. Side-by-side tasting of the Morning Delight, Assassin , KBBS (all 2013) and SR-71 (freshest).
All of the beers have a good dose of silky smooth and rich sweetness, molasses and roasted barley malts in them. All of them are great beers.
- Morning Delight: more on the freshly roasted coffee, some green paprica too, sometimes a bit too rich. 4.1/5
- Assassin: my personal favourite: very balanced aroma: slight alcohol that accentuates the subtle roasted coffee notes and chocolate, together with some oak and vanilla touch. 4.5/5
- KBBS: very thick and rich, loads of molasses. Nice barrel touch. 4.3/5
- SR-71: a lot more alcohol in the aroma, as well as peanuts and roasted nuts. 4.0/5

Bottle shared. Pours near black with a small brown head dissappearing quickly to a ring around the glass. Aroma of intense smooth coffee roast over everything else, with dark chocolate, molasses, fudge. Flavour is heavy sweet and bitter with a massive coffee and fudge, toffee palate leading into a long intense bitter finish. Full bodied with soft carbonation. Amazing.

33cl bottle courtesy of and shared with Kermis. Big thanks!
huge coffee aroma. Thin tan ring head. Clear black pour. Lots of coffee. Well balanced. Extremely enjoyable. An awesome brew
Great beer, I was really into it!!!!!!!! I would recommend this beer to anyone!!!!!!!

Sampled at GTMW 2014. Pours a dark black with a tan head. Aroma of coffee, chocolate, sugar. Flavor is very sweet with mild roast and dark malt bitterness towards the back end. Thick chewy mouthfeel, with creeping roast in the finish. This is too sweet for me.

330ml bottle at home, thanks AntonFred! Black color with small dark beige head. Aroma is roasted malty, a looot of coffee, chocolate, vanilla, a little bit spicy (like cinnamon?). Taste is roasted malty, heavy sweet, chocolate and vanilla and heavy bitter, roasted coffee, dark chocolate. Full body, silky creamy thick, soft to flat carbonation, with very long bitter coffee and dark chocolate aftertaste.

So the time is upon us where one rater has 100 more Iowa ratings than anyone else on the website. Enormous thanks to TheAlum for providing a bit of the beer to mark such an occasion. 

So this one pours an inky black with a nice head and nice lacing on the glass. 

The aroma is super sweet, chocolaty, vanilla and booze forward, with a good bit of coffee to it as well. Im not really doing it justice there, but its just impossibly rich smelling, inviting, brooding... etc. 

The flavor is rich & sweet, generally huge with a bunch of dark chocolate & coffee. It seems a bit odd, but I swear I got a touch of like a floral bitterness to it too, Im not sure what thats about,, but it was nice enough either way and provided not so much a balance, but a curious pleasant note that took the beer in a slightly less brooding direction. 

The mouthfeel is totally tongue coating & huge without being annoyingly gigantic. 
way way fun.

Sample at Great Taste of the Midwest on 08/09/2014: Pours pitch black with a medium creamy tan head that recedes gradually to a film. Partial rings of lacing. Aroma of roast malt, coffee and cocoa. Full-bodied with flavors of chocolate malt, sweet maple and coffee. The finish is sweet with a graham cracker and maple aftertaste. Enjoyable beer all around.

From memory from The Great Taste Of The Midwest in Madison. On tap poured a dark brown with a strong maple syrup aroma and brown head. Taste is strong maple syrup and coffee. I dont like coffee and the maple flavor tames the coffee flavor, and the coffee tames the maple flavor, than throw in some stout and there you go. I remember thinking where are the pancakes, but it isnt really thick enough for that. That was the best beer I have ever had, period.

Served side by side with KBBS and Assassin.

The beer is dark brown with an oily thin head. Aromas of whiskey, vanilla and coffee. Oak and whiskey. Mild heat. Huge malt bill with bourbon atop coffee. Roast character throughout and quite smooth on the palate. My least favorite of the three and its still world class. What?!?
On tap at dexters. Insane amount of coffee. Maple syrup. Thick as hell. Amazing. Nothing else to say.

12 oz bottle shared by Huhzubendah, thanks a ton Matt! Pours a near black with slight purple hues on the rim. Head is thin and mainly on the edge. Aroma is maple syrup poured over roasted malt, pancakes, and dark fruit syrup. Flavor is breakfast in a glass - smoky roasted malt, maple syrup, all balanced with a super secret brewers ingredient. Muted carbonation, syrupy mouthfeel, and delicious.

Bottle thanks to Minh. Pours a dark brown with medium creamy tan head that lasts. The aroma is an intense coffee, maple, oak, one of the best smelling beers I have ever come across. Thick mouthfeel with strong roast, maple flavor that lingers, strong coffee bean, and sweet syrupy finish. Wow, really enjoyed this one.

Backlog from RBSG 2014. Bottle shared by Adam I believe. Pour is stark black with a small brown head. Aroma is roasty and coffee with a dark chocolate undertone. The blend of all this in the nose was just amazing. All seemed to be there and work in harmony rather than fight for attention. Upon sampling the flavors are all intense and complimentary. Coffee, chocolate, light roast, but way short of burnt or astringent. A thick chewy mouthfeel, but not overly sweet or cloying. Didnt really get much maple syrup, but otherwise this was a fantastic beer. Thanks!

Black color. Thin brown ring of head. Good bits of lace. Good chewy texture, bigger body. Smooth, lighter carbonation. Moderate bitter taste, moderate sweet, good mild warmth, nothing bothersome at all. Wow, love that maple, and dark chocolate, and coffee roast. Hint of smoke. Oh my goodness, I love this aroma. Wow wow wow wow. Totally my style. Best stout Ive had since the 1st stout that blew my mind, FBS. Such good shit here. Hint of savory smoke even. a little bit of a maple syrup covered sausage patty factor here. holy shit, so good.
Bottle - Lots of dark roast coffee bean. Jet black with a rich brown head. Roast coffee, nice syrup sweetness to balance bitterness and a finish that will last the day.
Bottle. Again shared by the Adam. Thick black oily pour, mocha head. Aroma of maple syrup, coffee, and chocolate. Taste, chocolate, maple syrup, thick mouthfeel, smooth decadent finish. Wow.

Bottle pours out with a deep dark-void like body that spins up some staining on the side of the glass and supports a minimal head. The aroma comes across as oily rich dark roasted coffee goodness that has an espresso sense to it and also has thin supporting snippets of chocolate and molasses. The taste is similar with rich oily dark roasted coffee to espresso blending into a pleasing mix of molasses, chocolate and dark roasted malts. This is very nectar like and rich and wonderful where the whole thing just comes alive and begs to be dispatched of in an unhurried fashion. Terrific sipper if there ever was one.

Sampled @ Woodshed 3.0! Dak, once again, came through with this one! Pitch black pour with a creamy caramel cap that left a dense coating inside the glass. Rich fudge, Canadian maple syrup, a light dusting of cinnamon, vanilla cake, graham crackers, and waffle batter. Like eating a Sees Candy Milk Chocolate Bordeaux. Breakfast in a bottle!

UPDATED: JUN 29, 2014 Draft on Hunaphu day. Pours was black, with minimal head. Aroma of coffee and maple - yummy. Taste was equally great, maple, coffee, chocolate, thick in the mouth. Great beer. Probably the favorite from the day.

Bottle @ 10K + OT. Thanks, Gil! Black in color without any head. Viscous. Maple syrup, coffee, vanilla, and graham cracker on the nose. Toffee, a hint of peanut brittle, and plenty of chocolate. Nice bitter chocolate on the taste to balance out the sweet toffee, vanilla, and maple. Nice graham cracker, roast, and coffee, too. Well done all around. Another solid beer from Toppling Goliath.

> Sweeter creme brulee and maple stout
[ Bottle ][ Gil ][ 12oz ][ 10K+OT Tasting ][ Stemless Wine Taster ][ 5/3/14 ]
>> Huge thanks to Gil for the share! Copper wax. Pours inky sepia with low carbonation, no foam. Nose is creme brulee, raisin, marmite, chili pepper, smoke, no coffee (which may be a good thing). Taste is a bit sweet, Twizzlers, paper, bitter dark chocolate, Starbucks style mixed mocha concoction, maple, no coffee. Palate is semi dry and dusty. Creme brulee character is the highlight.
>!< no coffee, no carbonation, low bitterness
Dark black color with brown head. Chocolate and coffee smells. Coffee and dark chocolate tasteds
Draft at extreme beer festival, back log. Black syrupy pour with a nice Brown head. Nose is maple syrup. Tastes like pancakes and diabetes. Still awesome.

UPDATED: APR 4, 2014 On draught at EB, 3/22/14Dark, ebony/mahogany body has garnet highlights on the edges and a tan head that shows strong retention.Lovely dark fruits in the nose lead to coffee, for sure, but thankfully its very dark and vinous itself, blending in to the stout aspects of the beer quite artfully. SO VERY THANKFUL that this is not just a nose full of coffee beans and nothing else...Ahem, back to the beer, dark chocolate, dry vanilla and liquorous raisins. Hop notes are light, add some mild citrus notes but otherwise give the stout over to the malt. Very strong aroma and no sign of alcohol or any flaws.Departing again from the recent trend of stouts that you have to chew before swallowing, this stuff is actually only medium-full bodied. Carbonation is very tight and gives the beer a very engaging texture that wraps about the mouth spreading light prunes, bitter dark chocolate notes, sweet vanilla and moderate amounts of coffee flavor. Sweetness is on the low side and its not just a mouth full of sugary chocolate. On the finish there is a delicious, difficult to describe flavor, almost bourbon-like, or maple liqueur-like, though not as sweet as maple liqueur. Very interesting and delicious.Awesome stuff, shows a lot of restraint on the coffee and the beer is well-attenuated. Kind of rare these days when it comes to coffee stouts....

Taster sampled at EBF--wasnt planning on rating anything but felt strongly enough to include it. Inky black, burnt-caramel head. Aroma is maple, roasted almonds, burnt caramel, bitter chocolate, hazelnuts, coffee ice cream. Booze is well masked. Taste is sweet milky espresso and dulce de leche fading into bitter chocolate. Maple sugar. Creamy. Amazing.

On tap great coffee and maple taste. 
  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Will have to try again, my pour at EBF was absolutely incredibly good with rich notes of maple woven into chocolate and fudge. Just awesome.

Échantillonné du Extreme beer fest 2014: Celle-là ma giflé de sa perfection. Un café caramel grenache avec crème fouetté, guimauve, pacanes grillées, biscuits graham et soupçon fumé dans une marre donctuosité mouvante et irréel. Chaque gorgée me laisse figé, trop concentré, je suis, à décrypter ce que jai devant moi.

UPDATED: APR 2, 2014 sample at extreme beer fest, first tried of the night. Very hot, the alcohol burn takes over unfortuneatley. Very strong coffee and roast flavors, ash bitter finish. Some sweetness from the maple syrup but overwhelmed by all the other roast and ash. Decent.

On tap at the EBF Saturday
Probably one of the best coffee stouts Ive ever had. Highly recommended!

Really nice beer but not quite KBBS. Tastes like pancakes and coffee. Straight up syrupy sweet maple syrup and a cup o coffee. Some vanilla, mollasses, heavy maple. coffee, and candy sugar. Overall really good.
Pours a dark brown with a burnt caramel colored head. Notes of French toast coffee and maple syrup. Very sweet and syrupy.

Bottle 226/300. Pours pitch black with a thin mocha cap that fades to a ring, but can be revived with a swirl of the glass. Aromas a robust coffee, char, chocolates and syrup. Taste is loaded with coffee upfront, followed by the maple syrup sweetness. Very nice counterbalance to each other. Allowing the dark chocolates to add some more to the bitter/sweet harmony. There is a nice pancake-batter middle ground here...or maybe the maple syrup is drawing me in that direction...but the chewy body gives the palate that impression. The finish lingers with this heavy body coating the entire mouth. Very well-hidden booze over the syrup that clings for dear life. A semi-dry chocolate flavor sticks to the back of my tongue as the bitter coffees and char move past and into a warming alcohol sensation. Very big and robust. A bit overly sweet, making this a sipper and something that should be shared. (I did)
Black pour, creamy tan head. Nose is fresh coffee, some sweet maple syrup. Taste is coffee, maple syrup, chocolate, marshmallow. Creamy sticky mouthfeel.
One of my top two beers at Hunahpu. Waited in line a little while to start the fest, but it was worth it. Absolutely delicious!

This one poured a very dark brown with a tan head. Aroma was loads and loads of dark roasted coffee, burnt brown sugar, booze, and chocolate. Flavor was mostly coffee, really no maple, lighter booze, and very sweet. Pretty good, but not up to par with BCS coffee.

UPDATED: JUN 8, 2014 Black tan foam - great looking. Aroma is coffee roast plus maple. Medium carbonation, maple sweet up front with an espresso coffee style finish - so good. Palate is syrupy. Overall worth the hype. Great dessert beer - balanced so well for a big sweet stout. Coffee and maple in harmony.
Tap at hunahpu day! Ultra black pour with tan head with a nice solid ring. Wow huge coffee maple with hazelnuts. A bit sweet and thick coats your mouth. Heavy beer with some amazing flavor.
Pours pitch black good brown creamy lacing head. Aroma heavy coffee chocolate vanilla coconut barrel tones roasted malts a bit sweet. Flavor as aroma, intense delicious.
Nearly perfect. Super dark brown rich head, pitch black pour. Amazing coffee and roast aroma. Great coffee taste which melds into sweet maple syrup. Truly fantastic

Bottle  with insanely huge thanks to bytemesis. I need to get better at rating the beers you share with me. Enjoyed 8/16/2013. Aroma is mind numbingly luscious. Ridiculous espresso, fudge, brownies, maple syrup, Nutella, doughy, and vanilla. No joke when people say its like maple syrup covered pancakes. Pours super thick black with absolutely no light shining through and a faint brown lace on the side of the glass. Taste is surprisingly less sweet for a beer that commands this kind of aroma. The coffee works damn well with the fudge and maple syrup to cut out the sweetness. Nice espresso, mocha, brown sugar, coffee bean, roast and finally the maple, vanilla, molasses and milk chocolate. Body is crazy thick with low carbonation. The syrupy mouth isnt really distracting, but it definitely does leave a sticky feeling on the tongue. The finish is just non-stop fudge and maple with mocha/coffee hanging out on the tongue for days. Overall perhaps the best non-BA stout. The body is seriously perfect and each component of the flavor works perfectly together.

Pour is jet black with a burnt cappuccino head. Nose is a bit greener than kbbs, lots more coffee and a bit more simple. Some sugary sweetness behind. Taste is strong coffee, both are really clean coffee without any of that burnt acrid flavor. A little vanilla and marshmallow, a fair bit of malt sweetness in back but abrupt. The wood in kbbs added a lot, this gets just as sweet without the bourbon. The coffee is still really clean and nice for a coffee stout. The body is very creamy and the carb is light.

Im not sure if Ive wrote about a beer as much as I have about Mornin Delight. The original release garnered a bit of publicity, but it has blown up into much more since that wonderful Saturday morning in Decorah. This and the Kentucky Brunch release might highlight my favorite beer moments of 2013! The trade demand out there is incredibly high for this brew so if you still have a bottle of the greatness, count yourself lucky!
Bottle. Pours a black color with white head. Thanks to clevar for sharing. Big coffee, chocolate, burnt, roasty sweet, syrup flavors. Nice coffee flavors.

Bottle @ Armins house, courtesy of CLevar. Thanks! Pours a black appearance with a thin dark brown head. Super roasty coffee, pancake maple syrup, dark chocolate, light cola, cocoa aroma. Thick dark chocolate, a touch smoky, coffee, coffee, coffee, slightly burnt, gooey maple flavor. Çhïll beer; would pete again.

Bottle shared by Jim. From past notes. Pours thick and dark with little to no head. Aroma is coffee, chocolate and maple syrup. Flavor is everything Id expect from the aroma. Full bodied with a great mouth feel. I love this beer!

Opaque black pour, almost no lacing. Pleasantly sweet aroma of maple syrup, fresh espresso, milk chocolate, pancake batter, fluffy marshmallow, sticky caramel, and vanilla. Sweeter in taste with greater emphasis on the maple syrup, caramel, and pancake batter. Extremely slick, just coats the inside of your mouth. Smooth, creamy, and full-bodied without being overly heavy. Just a slight twang in the finish prevents it from a perfect score. Such an amazing blend of aromas and tastes.

Bottle from trade with Rob. Aroma and flavor of deep medium roast coffee, maple syrup, and Dove dark chocolate. Great underlying carbonation, medium mouthfeel, and excellent finish. Yes, this is definitely a top-15 beer.

12 oz. bottle, sent from mista (thanks so much, Geoff), pours a thick jet black with a small brown head. Nose is extremely strong, with loads of coffee, followed by maple syrup, molasses, and more roasted coffee beans. Flavour is amazingly rich and complex, with loads of espresso beans, followed by just enough maple syrup, decadent chocolate fudge, and more coffee. The beer isnt as sweet as I thought. The coffee cuts out any sweetness from the maple syrup that might be detracting. This is stunningly amazing. One of the best impie stouts out there.

Ok so here goes finally got one from Edkroper, thanks Ed you are the. Man, poured a thick dark black color with aromas of fresh pressed espresso with some oak, vanilla, light earth and some roast. Flavors were all coffee (the most coffee I ever had in a beer), maple syrup, roast, and some chocolate. Holy smokes was this beer amazing. Ed your the man I will send you what ever the hell you want if I can get any beers from these guys. Again somehow I owe you!

UPDATED: SEP 17, 2016 bottle side by side to kentucky brunch . 
179/300 
pours black , big brown head ( lighter than kentucky ) 
smell is superintence wallnuts , coffee, smooth as a daisy carbonation. very gentle, yet superintence. soft, bitter, chocolate, cofee, walnuts ( becoming very inence in the back ) damn awsome stuff ! 

Re-rate at  A day to sink all seasheppards  . Batch 2 this time, and not as fresh as the batch 1 was when I drank it. This time, I had loads of maple syrup. Less coffee, bit bitterness. The balance seems to be way better here. I was blown away, since I remember it as the least one of their mega-Imperial-stout-range. This turned out to be the best of that very range today ! Upping the score from 4.5 to a well-deserved 4.8

36cl, Bottle 179/300, new exclusive American brew Anno 2011, with coffee, thx alot to kraddel!, very complex sweet Stout, roasted/sweet and slightly fruity/woody, yet not too heavy, very balanced, cloudy, rocky head, world class!, Deserves its hype!
Bottle. From notes. Sampled at RBSG. Like coffee and pancakes in a bottle. This stuff kicks ass.

Bottle shared by dtmets84, 10/04/2013. Pours black, spotty tan head resting on the surface. Aroma is sweet vanilla, caramel coffee, bitter grounds, hazelnut and bourbon finish. Taste is rich chocolate, caramel vanilla cream, moderate coffee blending nicely with the barrel notes. Rich, thick body, creamy. Awesome.

dark with cappuccino ring. Nose is roasts, light anise and chocolate, heavy sugars throughout. Flavor is cream up front, incredibly sweet mid, like ice cream, ending sugary with icing notes. Thin slick profile, sugar coated tongue gasps for breath after its gone.

From a bottle during Ratebeer summer gathering. Very sweet maple and roasted malt. A very thick and heavy beer, rich and heavy. I would like to try the base beer without the maple, but I do like it very much.

A - pours oily thick black brown with no head and very little carb on the pour. S - holy shit balls! The most amazing combo of flourless hazelnut-chocolate tart and rich maple syrup covered pancakes. Quiet notes away like bourbony oak, graham cracker and marshmallow. Hints of tobacco, snicker doodles, nutmeg, maple syrup and booze. M - rich chewy mf. No carb. Full rich palate. Dry sticky end. T - a dessert and rich sweet breakfast in one. Espresso, chocolate-hazelnut tart, rich dark chocolate up front. The palate is tangy cacao, maple syrup covered pancakes, dark chocolate covered marshmallow graham crackers. The end is fudge brownies, tangy cacao, flourless chocolate tort, dry grains, and maple syrup. O - astoundingly good. Worth the hype and worth the trade. Shenanigans. 9+

12oz bottle-brown-black with somew sheeting. A-a diner @7:99AM, roasty/some coffee/molasses/maple syrup-dk malt/oat. T-a diner @7:99AM, roasty/some coffee/molasses/maple syrup-dk malt/oat, some earthy hops. First sip gave a brief burn into the nasal passage.

On tap at GTMW, generously shared by CaseyK...thanks Casey, ya big lug - Welp, here we go! Pours black with a thin tan head. Looks like a beer I would have loved in my stout phase three years ago. Nose has tons of dark roast coffee, roasty malt, pancakes (!), chocolate, and a good deal of maple. How did they do this? Taste is more dark roast, chocolate chip pancakes, and a big maple finish. Wow. I was a bit skeptical, and this isnt my favorite style anymore, but man is this good. The 12% is nowhere to be found, and its surprisingly easy drinking. Its sweet, but not in a cloying way. Thick and slick just as Id expect--damn...Im blown away.
Smell of pancake batter and coffee. Breakfast in a glass. Taste of roasted coffee, maple syrup, slightly sweet with an intense burst of coffee. One of the best stouts ive had

UPDATED: AUG 28, 2013 Bottle shared at Amarin. Pours dark reddish brown. Nose and taste of pancake syrup, pancake batter, coffee beans, green pepper (likely a "flaw" from the coffee, but seriously this is so awesome I dont care), Cuban highly concentrated coffee and milk chocolate. Thick mouthfeel. Tongue coating.

Gut myself a pour of this @ Dexters at The Great Taste Eve.. 
Pour a beatiful pitch black, with a small dense, somewhat creamy and mocha-brown head. 
Aroma is really coffee-forward, but theres a lot of vanilla, chocolate, cacao and slight roasted malts inhere as well.. Oh.. And of course crazy amounts of maple syrup.. mmmhh... Id like to have myself some flapjacks with this one.. 
The taste is pretty darn sweet, but is very balanced with a long and roasted bitterness... Full bodied with a slightly oily texture, and a semi-flat carbonation.. I dig this for sure..

Multiple taster glasses at the Great Taste in Madison. It smells like a breakfast blend of maple, Hersheys chocolate pancakes, and a bit of Irish coffee with cream. The taste is big and bold and smooth too, matching up perfectly with the welcoming aroma and the dollop dropping body. Flavors inlcude milk chocolate, coffee, well-incorporated maple syrup sweetness and just some toffee. Theres something additional here too, a doughy cookie batter chewiness, that sets it apart from other stouts that have those traditional coffee-milk-chocolate aspects. Rich and smooth in body, motor oil heavy and moderately carbonated. Overall, this was my favorite stout at the 2013 Great Taste. This stuff is worth seeking out.

This beer was perfect in every way. I enjoyed it on my visit and revisited it before the review. I was amazed when drank my bottle that is was as good as my first taste. Like drinking a chocolate pancake with syrup and coffee.

Bottle at RBSG courtesy of Clark. Pour is dark with minimal head. Aroma is incredible coffee, maple syrup and more coffee. Flavor is code
coffee, maple syrup, very sweet..A bit cloying, stuck to my mouth for hours.

[Bottle at RBSG, thanks TG!] Pours black with no head. Aroma explodes out of the glass with coffee and maple syrup. The taste is again ridiculously huge with maple syrup and coffee. Flavors really meld together well. Not very complex at all, but avoids any char taste, and very enjoyable. Thick, smooth, extremely long finish. A common complaint about beers I have is that they are one dimensional. I cant say that in this case, but I would say that it does lack complexity and is "two dimensional". That having been said, I did really enjoy this, and for a sweet dessert beer in small quantities it is great.

(bottle shared at the RBSG brunch) Pours jet black with a dark tan head that quickly settles to a thin ring around the glass. Aroma is very potent, and the maple syrup really dominates proceedings, and it serves to mask the coffee component underneath, which improves the beer as I can smell some vegetal snap pea and green bell scents emanating from the coffee undertone. With more air, some sweeter scents of Reeses peanut butter cups, walnuts, and raisins make their presence known, which does improve things. The flavor also heavily emphasizes the maple syrup, and along with that is an abundant amount of chocolate, peanut butter cup, and roasted malt. Very sweet. The coffee again is pretty suppressed by the sweeter flavors but some ash and greenness is evident towards the finish, although its not nearly as glaring as it is in the aroma. Mouthfeel is medium and carbonation is appropriate.

Bottle. Wow, what a treat. Clark was kind enough to bring some bottles from his private stash to the RBSG brunch event at the Republic. Pours a dark brown with a dark mocha head. Swirling coats the glass with a brown coating. This baby is thick! The aroma is just fantastic with notes of maple right off the bat, molassess, some dark chocolate, and roast. Heavy mouthfeel, chewy. As in the aroma, the flavor starts off with a sweet maple syrup note which transitions to a dark coffee note at the end. It literlly is like eating and maple pancake and then taking a big drink of your fresh brewed coffee. I will say that this beer is fairly sweet though, I could probably slolwy drink a whole bottle over the sourse of an hour or so but for this occassion 4-6oz was perfect. Very nice and glad to hear TG will stepping up production on this gem.

Bottle at RBSG (thanks Clark!) Rich dark black pour, nose was coffee and green pepper. Flavor was incredibly well balanced dark chocolate, coffee, a little syrupy sweetness on the finish. Worthy of the high praise it has received.

UPDATED: DEC 9, 2015 3 samples at rePUBlic for RBSG. Thanks Clark for sharing with us! Pours jet black with a dark brown head forming after 5 seconds or so. Aroma is overwhelming chocolate, molasses, coffee, and pretty much all ingredients it takes to make bananas foster. Such a huge banana desert component to this I could compare it to just about any sweet cream + banana combination. Bananas foster? Sure. Banana split? Why not. Big sweet creamy bananas. Not a bad thing really, but this beer is sticky sweet. Carbonation is dialed in perfect for the style. For a desert beer, this is well above average. This style has been less and less interesting to me the more Ive had, but this one is great for what it is going for.

Pours oily black with a thin tan coating head that dissipates to a thin collar. Aroma has amazing butterscotch toffee and coffee. Taste is rich butterscotch toffee caramel chocolate faint bitterness. Fucking amazing! Palate is full slick sticky, just awesome! My new all time favorite!

Bottle courtesy of the brewer at RBSG Mpls! Super thick viscous dark pour with a tan head. Coffee and maple syrup aroma. Very dense palate. Sticky sweet, coffee, maple syrup taste. Ridiculously good! Outside of a bourbon barrel aged beer (personal preference), not sure Ive ever had a better one.

Draft at GTMW eve event. The aroma is amazing, strong coffee and sweet chocolate. The taste is absolutely amazing. Drinks thick with tons of coffee and sweet flavors. The best non-BA beer I have ever had, so very glad I got a chance to try this one. Cheers to TG!

Bottle 287 of 300 for rating # 5200:   Super huge thanks to skyview for the opportunity to try this.   Deep black pour, moderate tannish head, little lacing.   Whoa!   Super strong nose of peppers and 

cinnamon.   Roasted malts are also present.   Smooth, thick, roasted malts up front.   Strong pepper and cinnamon.   So thick, chewy, flavorful, spicy, yet sweet.   This is an abnormality!   Wonderful body and 

mouthfeel, thick but not cloying, heavy yet smooth.   This is just wonderful!   Spicy, yet sweet, roasty and slightly hoppy.   This beer is so well balanced I am beside myself.   Feels fantastic on the tongue.   This 

beer is literally like a meal.   Body and mouthfeel are absolutely full bodied and chewy.   This is easily one of the best Imperial Stouts I have ever had.   Such a wonderful spicy yet sweet profile.   Its like a 

mouthgasm each time I sip this one.   Real rich, chewy, spicy, but sweet with cinnamon and rich roasted malts, cocoa, chocolate, and pure love.   Whomever made this in such small quantities really knew what they were doing.   

300 bottles?   Really?   You need to brew more of this and show the world how this should be done.   Probably my 2nd favorite Imperial Stout outside of the BA Poseidon from Fish Tale.   Simply well crafted and unique. 

  I could go on and on and on...   I will let the numbers speak for themselves.   Bob, I hope you were able to try this because this is not only a top 50 beer, it should be in the top 5.   Simply and utterly a 

masterpiece.   After 5200 rates, I am simply amazed by this one. It is #13 now (up from 17 as of my rate), on the 11th of August 2013, but will it move upwards even more?   Friggen amazing!!
Coffee, cream, chocolate, caramel, vanilla, toffee, brown sugar, syrup. Sweet, roasty, smooth alcohol.. Awesomely amazing.

Tap. Black. Fair brown head, lasting ring around glass, some lace. Breakfast desert. Coffee, espresso, chocolate, milk chocolate, caramel, vanilla, toffee, brown sugar, syrup. Sweet, roasty, smooth alcohol. Rich and voluptuous. A real treat. Among the best beers Ive had.

Amazing. Very sweet. Hard to drink a lot of but it's not cloying sweet. Lots of brewed coffee flavor, maple, and a lactose sweetness/tang. Almost like a great iced coffee. Very unique and unlike anything I've had before. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Shared Bottle from the whale master Brent. Pours black and viscous with nice tan tolight brown head. nose is burnt sugar, molasses, and roasted malt. first sip is similar with pancake syrup, dark and milk chocolate with a silky mouth feel. finish is slight french pressed coffee. amazing stuff!

UPDATED: APR 20, 2014 Sample at STL craft beer week event at Perennial. Pour is black with almost no had. Aroma is like an espresso bean covered in English toffee: huge espresso, buttery brown sugar, maple syrup, and lightly roasty. One of the best aromas I have encountered. Flavor is also really solid but not as impressive as the aroma. More coffee in the flavor with roasted malt, light maple, and light vanilla.  Update 4/20/14 - Larger sample this time - just amazing.  Much better than I remember. So rich and velvety.  Just amazing.

Sampled at Belgian Beer Fest. Thanks Ben for handing me some of this. An almost black beer that smelled delicious. The maple and coffee were beyond nice. Flavor was again maple and coffee. The coffee was strong and a bit acrid. Oak and so much roast. The feel was kind of chalky. This is a fine beer.

Sampled twice from two different bottles at Dark Lord Day 2013.

Pours black, tan mocha-colored head, thin ring, some bubbles on top. Nose is very rich, lots of chocolate, smooth booze, oak, coffee. Flavor is better then the nose, lots of sweet/smooth booze, chocolate, perfect barrel character, coffee, burnt sugars. Medium to full body, little to no carbonation, creamy rich finish.

A great beer, no doubt...for me, this lived up to the hype thats surrounding this brewery. Hopefully, Ill be able to sample more in the near future!

Bottle This beer rocks! Pours Marshall Zhukov black with a small, creamy, well-tanned head. The aromatic highlights are Cuban-roast coffee, maple syrup, dark chocolate, charred malts, vanilla and pouch tobacco. Full-bodied and chewy with lazy carbonation. The flavor is a collection of acrid, burnt, bittersweet malts, Cuban-roast coffee and ethanol. Finishes burnt, bittersweet and gently warming. Big-time thanks goes out to badbeer for providing this world class brew!

Bottle thanks to Hopscotch. Black with very little head. The nose on this beer is so freaking good! Smells like breakfast in a glass. Wow, just so smooth and incredibly tasty. My favorite of the bunch. Thanks Eric!

Bottle (* of 300). Huge thanks to Hopscotch for sharing this beast. Joan Jett black pour with a brown head. Huge maple syrup aromas. It truly is breakfast in a glass. Maple syrup, black coffee, dark roasted malts, bitter chocolate. Great mouthfeel and body. Impressive...

Bottle Thanks Hopscotch - Pours dark black, brown head, and viscosity. Smells of lots of great maple syrup, coffee, and breakfast. Tastes of chocolate, coffee, maple, and vanilla. Amazing balls!!!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
P blk tan head nose sweet creme brulee iced coffee fl sweet cocoa, coffee and cream, milk chocolate, cream brulee, sweet good stuff

Thanks to whoever shared this.  Poured a deep rich black.  Aroma is of chocolate and maple.  Flavor is rich and roasty.  Wonderful chocolate and coffee notes.  Waves of maple and vanilla then cut through.  Talk about breakfast in a bottle!   A stupid good beer.
Bottle. Pours black solid tan head. Big coffee maple aroma, slight soy. Taste is so damn good. Pancakes syrup cup of coffee mouth feel is amazing.

Bottle to snifter (shared by mikem409; BIG thanks, bro!). Looks good; a viscous dark cola with mocha lacing. Smells great; dark malt, maple, coffee, and light soy sauce. Tastes like it smells with a syrupy but nice mouthfeel. This is damn good beer!
a shockingly great beer. The maple syrup is pure decadence, easy to drink with alcohol hidden nicely. I wouldnt want more than 4 oz but Id savor every last drop.

Bottle - thanks to "you know who you are!" Well, it finally happened. Pushing 1500 beers and no 5.0 ratings. Boom. Pours deep rich opaque reddish black with a secondary deep brown head that bubbles up from the depths leaving some lacing on the glass. Aroma knocks your socks off - coffee, roasted malts, maple all intermingle into a wonderful bocquet. Taste is the same, medium sweet but far from cloying, chocolate notes, well cut with a nice coffee bitterness that lingers through the finish. What an amazing fusion - the maple sweetness is perfectly balanced by the bitterness of the roast. Full bodied, syrupy creamy mouth coating palate. I wish I had a case of this at home! Yay to Toppling Goliath, my new favorite brewery!

Bottle courtesy of bytemesis. Big thank you, incredible beer. Black/deep brown, not a lot of head but respectable for an imperial stout. Awesome aroma, sweet with some maple syrup/brown sugar, small amount of coffee beans. Taste is even better, like breakfast in a can without being cloying. Maple, coffee, cocoa (but not much), a bit ashy bitter in the finish from the roast. One of those beers that pushes the style in new directions, very distinctive. One of the best i have had.

Holy shit. Thank you TheAlum. Bottle 260. Black color, reddish brown head. Aroma of coffee, chocolate coffee creamer, maple syrup, roast, dark chocolate. Sweet and toasty, roasted marshmallow, toffee, bitter chocolate, maple syrup, rich espresso. Amazing. Stunning.

UPDATED: JAN 11, 2014 Pour out of 375 mL bottle, thick black pour with creamy tan head, aroma brought notes of huge maple syrup, lots of coffee, roast, hints of chocolate, toffee, nice dark fruits, this is awesome.  Taste is a mix of dark chocolate, lots of sweet maple, dark coffee, espresso, roast, nice earth, finishing fairly sweet, slightly roasted, bitter.

UPDATED: APR 3, 2014 After having this again at Huna Day, Im upping my rating from a 4.6 to a 4.8.  Mornin Delight is nothing short of revolutionary. 
Original Rating (2013-05-11): Thanks Mac! Beautiful pour: black body, deep brown head retains lace stubbornly. Incredible depth & intensity in this coffee aroma that rivals the very best brews Ive ever smelled.

Decadent, roasty malt & coffee on the palate. Boozy character integrates perfectly, soothing my throat as I swallow. Goddamn incredible. And the mouthfeel is even more impressive: silky body is about as viscous as it gets, yet retains some carbonation. Coats my entire mouth with each sip. Only the Pegs stouts can compete on mouthfeel. Jesus this is good.

Phenomenal! Only a handful of stouts ever approach this level of refinement. One of the absolute best Ive ever consumed.

Wow, this beer is incredible. Pours dark and thick, black in color with a thick viscosity. The aroma brings coffee and sweet maple blended so well with just the smallest hint of booze. There is so much maple in the aroma, and then the flavor, it is so delicious! Just add pancakes as advertised is so accurate! The body is so thick with big flavors of vanilla, then maple, caramel, toffee, and then a bit of coffee that settle well on the tongue.

Bottle shared by TheAlum at DLD 2013- thanks again, Adam! Pours a deep, mostly opaque brown with a dark tan head. Holy cow, this thing smells like breakfast. Maple syrup, coffee, brown sugar, caramel, chocolate- I want to pour this on my pancakes. The flavor has a lot of coffee and some dark chocolate bitterness, and I think some earthy hops actually come through. Full-bodied, with a rich, roasty, sweet mouthfeel. So unique and tasty. Really close with the Assassin. These are world class imperial stouts in every way, and not for the faint of heart.

UPDATED: JUN 15, 2013 A viscous and downright syrupy stout, good for breakfast and good in smaller doses. Had another bottle. Wow this is a great beer, smells terrible but a nice maple, vanilla, coffee tasting beer.

UPDATED: AUG 17, 2013 Small pour from bottle, thanks Dan.  Oily black with no head.  Aromas of maple, pancake batter, hint of roast.  Very thick, strong coffee, batter, sweet.  Nice beer, great aroma, oily and thick  but a bit overcarbed.  

Third time trying this at republic. The coffee has gotten really bitter and acidic. Not impressed at all this time.

April 20, 2013 - bottle shared by Brandon.  Black pour with tan head that faded quickly.  Foamed up nicely with a slight twirl and stained the glass.  Aroma was sugary sweetness, slight alcohol and a nice roast / smoke.  Taste was consistent with aroma.  Medium to full bodied and smooth.  And I would be remiss to not mention the bottle number, yep bottle number 69.

UPDATED: MAY 17, 2013 Draft at TG on Assassin release day. Coffee, chocolate and a hint of maple in the nose. Super dark black pour. Great mouthfeel - I cant think of a better way to start off your day!

Edit 5/17/13 - had another taste of this with Armin and Caleb. Warmer than when I had it at the brewery, much bigger maple and coffee tones - yum!!

Draft at TG Assassin Day 2013.  Pours pitch black with frothy dark tan head.  Aroma reminds me of Starbucks caramel instant coffee, but some maple syrup as well.  Mouthfeel is super thick and syrupy.  Flavor is very sweet and heavy with maple syrup, but balanced well by the bitterness of the coffee.  Alone, the coffee or maple flavors would be overwhelming, but they seem to balance well.  Finishes with some alcohol burn.  Fantastic beer. but you certainly have to be in the mood for something super sweet.

UPDATED: APR 15, 2013 On tap at Toppling Goliath, super rich dark brown/black, thick creamy caramel color head. Aroma is coffee, chocolate, syrup and donuts. Taste is coffee with a boozy kick, finishes with a nice syrup and has a nice lingering coffee bitter, outstanding! ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: JUL 11, 2013 Had this one twice, once waiting in line for tickets for the gtmw and then again at the taste sweet and cloying a big mess of sugar and maple a sample is all anybody could really handle its their inturpation of CBS worth a try but dont trade the house for it.

UPDATED: SEP 25, 2012 On tap at GTMW,  pours black with a thick dark tannish head with a ton of lacing through the entire glass, looks awesome, the aroma has a ton of chocolate, coffee and a nice sweetness to it as well, the flavor is a great mixture of both chocolate, vanilla and coffee.  The maple syrup shows up in the finish with a nice sweetness that works almost perfectly, this was one of the major highlights of the fest, well done.

GTMW 2012.  This was such an exciting beer to try, as I heard all the talk about this new Iowa brewery and the astonishing work they are doing.  Well, I wasnt dissapointed by this beer from my prior home-state brewery.  The beer pours inky black with a brown head and excellent lacing.  Aromas of chocolate, coffee, and maple syrup.  Flavors of the same, and perhaps a light creosote to boot.  Silken mouthfeel and no alcohol to be had.  The brewery lives up to the hype.  Seek it out!

Enjoyed at GTMW 2012. Pours a dark, thick cocoa black with a cream head. Smells of coffee, caramel and chocolate. Creamy taste of slightly sour chocolate, caramel and a touch of orange. Brief aftertaste of the same.

UPDATED: APR 16, 2013 Draft pour on tap at GTMW 2012 (Madison, WI). Pours a rich deep opaque blackish pour, rich and thicker. Frothy brownish head, thicker film with good lacing. Aromas are rich coffe roast and toffee. Good vanilla, good rich coffee, cocoa, and richf lavors. Initial is thicker, rich cofffee and cocoa flavors. Great flavors, with vanilla, toffee, and toast. Some thickness into the middle, a bit sweet. Finish is rich, coffee, roast and dryness. Pretzels, great rich flavors. Some more coffee elements. Smell is on, beer is good. 
Edit: On tap at the 2013 Assassin Release. This beer is still rich, powerful, and potent. Full bodied, rich maple and coffee flavors, cool vanilla and some good roast, cocoa, and all around assertive flavors. Sipped on glasses of this that I shared all day. It would be hard to drink more than a glass or two, but on and off throughout the day it really worked. I really enjoyed this and upped the score overall by one. The nose was still on and powerful, the flavors just great and overall, just a lovely experience. Cant wait till the next release.

GTMW.  Deepest of black pour.  Aroma is completely overwhelming.  Straight, permeating, thick fresh roasted coffee.  I cannot understate this.  Perfectly lets out little pockets of sweet maple syrup.  Flavor is the real deal.  Again, huge, huge fresh coffee flavor.  Very earthy.  Sweet sticky maple syrup, roasted malt, and brown sugar.  Coffee and light maple sweetness lingers and lingers.  No real acidity from the coffee.  Semi-gritty and chewy, but in the best possible way.  Thick on the palate.  Sweet enough to be enticing, but not sweet enough to be detracting.  Unbelievably good.  This is my perfect beer.  Period.

5 oz pour at Dexters Pub, pre-GTMW. Oily, viscous black pour with dark espresso-colored head. Okay lacing, thick ribbons of alcohol legs. Huge maple syrup on the nose, also big on the coffee, barrel notes, and brown sugar. Super, super sweet: more maple syrup, molasses, fresh black coffee, some rich chocolate in there as well. I imagine this is what CBS sort of tastes like. Either way, a really excellent beer, if cloyingly sweet.

Jet black pour tiny brown head legs and lace.  I would guess a touch of bourbon a bunch of maple syrup a hint of coffee and some extra sugar.  Fuel well coated palate.  Almost a touch of bacon in the swallow with tons of maple syrup a hit of coffee.  Nearly perfect but a touch to sweet.

On tap into a tulip shaped glass.  Coffee, maple syrup, vanilla aromas, and taste.  Very black, with minimal lacing, and a one-finger head.  Decent carbonation.  It was not astringent either, and the 12.8% ABV was very well hidden.  I would drink as much of this as possible as often as I could.  To bad the brewery is two hours away though.  HIGHLY RECOMMENDED.

On tap at TG.  Massive espresso nose, probably the nicest coffee aroma Ive come across, like sticking your nose in a bag of freshly roasted oily coffee beans.  Also some caramel in the aroma, chocolate, malty sweetness, fantastic.  Pours an opaque inky black, brown head with good retention, leaves some lacing and coats the glass.  Flavor is very tasty coffee, smooth with no astringency, chocolate and hints of maple syrup and vanilla, roasty, more espresso, fairly sweet.  Very full body, medium carbonation, very smooth and creamy, coats the palate.  Coffee flavors and aromas in this beer are amazing, well done.

On tap at GTMW.  Poured oily black with no head and heavy viscosity.  The aroma picked up sweet Aunt Jemima over a fine blend of dark malts.. decadent, and I really wanted it over pancakes.  The flavor found sweet maple, vanilla, and more pancake syrup over coffee and roasty black patent maltage.. more bitter toward the back, with rising coffee roast.. just delicious!  Syrupy, heavy, and coating on the palate.. sweet.. this struck the right chords with me!
